Bitcoin – An Introduction 1

How do we come to use bitcoin as a legitimate method of payment? Let’s take
it from the beginning.

In the United States people use money to transact. That is the standard way
of doing things. One party has currency that is recognized as valuable by
the other party and that currency can be used in exchange for goods and
services.

In layman’s terms, what it really comes down to is that whatever is being
exchanged only has to have value to the two parties involved. This is what
is referred to as a “medium of exchange.” What would be accepted by the
other individual? Nothing else really matters.

If the parties can agree to a deal where each feels he or she is getting
equal value, then there is a transaction.

Of course, one could trade two Mark McGwire baseball cards for a Mickey
Mantle card and there could be value found on both ends. But for that
“barter” deal to happen, both parties would have to want the specific cards
in question. There would have to be what is known as a “coincidence of
wants” and this severely limits the scope of transactions from many
perspectives, including that of time. This is nothing to be taken lightly.

When a currency that is common to many is used, it makes for easier,
smoother transactions that do not have to suffer from the constraints of
barter deals. Of course, money, whether it be U.S. or Canadian dollars,
Euros, Rand or any other kind of commonly-accepted exchange medium, is
regulated by government entities; this is known as “fiat currency.” As
such, it is subject to laws, or lack of same, that would tend to de-value
it. Governments do not customarily back it, and as you can imagine, this is
not a good thing.

In the quest for a currency that could be universal, not dominated by
government and/or political interests, yet still hold a value for those who
wish to participate in it, came the concept for bitcoin, which provides for
a medium of exchange that can be accepted by those who have it, and
acquired by those who want it. It is the perfect “libertarian” currency
because there is an atmosphere of self-governance to it that actually works
in a more orderly fashion than that of, for example, the U.S. dollar, which
can be printed at will by government decree, thus creating inflation, which
is obviously not a healthy situation.

Bitcoin cuts through all of that and creates a dynamic by which
transactions for goods and services can not only take place anonymously,
but without the interference of government or banks. And there are no
worries about inflationary effects, since the supply of bitcoin will be
limited to 21 million.

If you want to put the operation of this system into another perspective,
think about it like a cell phone carrier where those who owned phones on
that particular network could call each other, while those who were not
connected to that network couldn’t. Having bitcoin plugs an individual or
entity into a network in such a way as to facilitate activity with others
on that network. And it creates a common thread between those parties that
makes transactions not only very possible, but a pleasurable and preferred
way of conducting business and commerce.
